questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the surgical emergency with a history of peptic ulcer disease and pain in abdomen, bloating, and obstipation for 3 days. What is the next line in management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Given scenario of history of peptic ulcer disease with acute abdomen suggests a peptic ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids: Administering intravenous (IV) fluids is essential to address potential dehydration or peritonitis, to stabilise the patient.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen): Performing a CECT abdomen is a diagnostic step that can help identify the cause of the patient's symptoms, such as complications related to peptic ulcer disease, including perforation or other abdominal pathologies.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there are signs of a surgical emergency, such as peritonitis or suspected perforation.

 

In summary, option D is correct because it covers the initial steps in managing this patient comprehensively, including addressing fluid balance (IV fluids), diagnostic imaging (CECT abdomen), and considering surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy) if indicated by the clinical presentation and imaging findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perforation of a hollow viscus is a life-threatening condition caused by the rupture of the alimentary tract.
  • This results in the leakage of enteric contents, leading to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation.
  • Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management includes IV fluids and exploratory laparotomy.

choices.text: Perforation of the intestine

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with hypotension, raised JVP, muffled heart sounds, engorged neck veins. He died in the hospital and an autopsy was done which showed the following image. The most likely cause of death in this patient would be? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac tamponade

 

The explanation given above is of Beck’s Triad:

 

  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Distended neck veins
  • Hypotension

 

X ray finding - enlarged cardiac shadow

 

Investigation of choice: 2D ECHO → for diagnosis

 

Rx: Emergency Rx → needle pericardiocentesis

 

Treatment of choice → surgical pericardiotomy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Heart rupture:

 

  • Heart rupture is a tear in the wall of the heart muscle. It's typically associated with a recent myocardial infarction (heart attack).
  • While heart rupture can lead to blood filling the pericardial space and subsequently causing cardiac tamponade, the presented triad of symptoms (Beck’s Triad) is more suggestive of an acute cardiac tamponade, which is the immediate cause of the symptoms rather than the heart rupture itself.

 

Option C. Perforation of the intestine:

 

  • Perforation of the intestine leads to the release of the contents of the intestine into the peritoneal cavity, leading to peritonitis.
  • Common symptoms include severe abdominal pain, fever, and abdominal distension.

 

Option D. Pneumonia:

 

  • Pneumonia is an inflammatory condition of the lung affecting primarily the alveoli, which might be filled with fluid or pus.
  • Symptoms usually include productive cough, chest pain, fever, and difficulty breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck's Triad: hypotension, raised JVP, and muffled heart sounds. Immediate treatment includes needle pericardiocentesis.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 24-h pH monitoring

 

24-hr pH monitoring is done in GERD. The above image is suggestive of gradual narrowing in lower esophagus, likely to be achalasia.

 

This is a test that measures the pH of the esophagus over a 24-hour period to assess for abnormal acid reflux. While not typically necessary for the diagnosis of achalasia cardia, 24-hour pH monitoring may be used to rule out gastroesophageal reflux disease as a potential cause of dysphagia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timed barium study: In the case of achalasia cardia, the barium will be retained in the esophagus for more than five minutes and the study may reveal a dilated esophagus with a 'bird's beak' appearance at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Option B. Endoscopy: Endoscopy may be used to rule out other potential causes of dysphagia, such as esophageal cancer, and to obtain biopsy samples if needed.

 

Option C. Esophageal manometry: This is a diagnostic test that measures the pressure and motility of the esophagus during swallowing. In the case of achalasia cardia, esophageal manometry may reveal incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. It is the test of choice for diagnosis of achalasia.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the treatment of a patient who presented with the following as shown in the image? Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical excision with herniorrhaphy

 

The clinical scenario presented is that of an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. This suggests the hernia has become complicated, possibly due to incarceration or strangulation, where the contents are trapped, leading to ischemia or gangrene of the herniated tissue. The overlying skin also appears gangrenous and requires excision.

 

The correct management involves surgical intervention to excise the affected umbilical tissue and perform herniorrhaphy, which is a repair of the hernia without the use of a mesh, particularly when there are complications such as strangulation or infection. The surgical approach must address both the excision of compromised tissue and the closure of the hernial defect to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical excision: This option only addresses the excision of the skin and does not treat the underlying hernia. Simply excising the umbilical tissue will not resolve the hernia defect or prevent recurrence, making this option inadequate.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not a definitive treatment for a hernia. While antibiotics may be used if there is an associated infection, they do not resolve the underlying mechanical problem of a hernia.

 

Option D. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses and localized infections but not for hernias. There is no indication of an abscess in this scenario; rather, it is a hernia with possible ischemic or gangrenous changes, requiring surgical repair rather than drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of complicated umbilical hernias, especially when the hernia becomes irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision and herniorrhaphy is necessary to repair the hernia and prevent further complications.

choices.text: Small frequent meals, increase protein content
Reverse Bilroth II to Bilroth I/Roux-en-Y

questions.text: What is the initial management for a patient who presents with diarrhea within 15 minutes of meals, after having undergone a Bilroth II gastrectomy? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Small frequent meals, increase protein content

 

 

The patient has undergone a Bilroth II gastrectomy, which involves a distal gastrectomy with a gastrojejunal anastomosis.

 

This surgical procedure can lead to a condition known as dumping syndrome. Dumping syndrome occurs when food, especially sugar, moves from the stomach into the small intestine too quickly.

 

There are two types of dumping syndrome:

 

  • Early dumping syndrome: Occurs within 5 to 20 minutes after eating. Symptoms include diarrhea, bloating, dizziness, and tachycardia.
  • Late dumping syndrome: Occurs 1 to 3 hours after eating. Symptoms are similar but occur later.

 

The initial management of dumping syndrome, whether early or late, involves dietary modifications:

 

  • Small, frequent meals.
  • Increased protein content to stabilize blood sugar levels.
  • Avoidance of high glycemic index foods such as milkshakes, sodas, and refined flour products.
  • Avoidance of very liquid meals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reverse Bilroth II to Bilroth I/Roux-en-Y: This is incorrect as a first-line management as it involves another surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Insulin: This is incorrect as insulin is used for blood sugar management in diabetes, not for dumping syndrome.

 

Option D. Symptomatic Rx: This does not specify any dietary modifications required to manage dumping syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of dumping syndrome after a Bilroth II gastrectomy is dietary modification, specifically small frequent meals with increased protein content and avoiding high glycemic index foods.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not performed via the perineal approach in a patient with rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein operation

 

This procedure is designed to treat rectal prolapse. It involves fixing the rectum to the sacrum using a synthetic mesh. This procedure is performed via an abdominal approach and not through the perineum. Hence, the answer to the question is A) Ripstein operation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiersch operation: The Thiersch operation is a perineal procedure. It involves placing a wire or other synthetic material around the anus to encircle and narrow it. This provides support to the anal canal and rectum, helping to prevent or treat rectal prolapse.

 

Option C. Altemeier procedure: Also known as the perineal rectal resection, the Altemeier procedure is a surgical treatment for rectal prolapse. During this operation, the prolapsed portion of the rectum is resected, and the remaining rectum is sutured back to the anal canal. This procedure is performed through the perineal approach.

 

Option D. Delorme operation: The Delorme operation is a perineal approach to treat rectal prolapse. The mucosa and submucosa of the prolapsed rectum are excised, and the muscularis is plicated. The remaining mucosa is then sutured back. This procedure is typically reserved for older patients or those who are not candidates for a more invasive abdominal procedure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent a bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

 

  • Pain in the thigh (Meralgia Paraesthetica) is due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve entrapment often occurs during laparoscopic hernia repair, especially during the placement of mesh.
  •  The nerves commonly injured in laparoscopic repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
  •  Patients with lateral cutaneous nerve injury present with acute neuropathic pain along the dermatomal distribution, resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Treatment consists of rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and possible local corticosteroid and anesthetic injection.
  • Drugs like gabapentin can be used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • In laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) repair, to reduce the chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve leads to sensory disturbances and pain over the skin of the genitalia and upper medial thigh. This nerve is most commonly injured in open repair of inguinal hernia, not laparoscopic repair.

 

Option B. Iliohypogastric nerve: The iliohypogastric nerve leads to pain in the inguinal and suprapubic regions. Injury to this nerve does not typically result in pain isolated to the thigh.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: Femoral nerve injury presents as lower limb numbness, weakness, tingling, paralysis, or pain along the nerve. However, femoral nerve injury is less likely to be caused by laparoscopic hernia repair and more often associated with other surgical procedures or traumatic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain in the thigh, is commonly due to entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, especially following laparoscopic hernia repair.
  •  Proper placement of mesh and tacks during surgery is crucial to avoid this nerve injury.

questions.text: Which type of thyroid carcinoma has the least likelihood of lymph node metastasis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid

 

Explanation: 

 

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid has the least likelihood of lymph node metastasis among the given options. Follicular carcinoma typically presents as a solitary thyroid nodule with a strong tendency for hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread. While it commonly metastasizes to bones (particularly thoracic vertebrae and skull) via blood vessels, lymph node involvement is rare, except in the Hurthle cell variant which may show lymph node metastases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because papillary carcinoma has a high propensity for lymph node metastasis. It frequently spreads to Level VI (central compartment) lymph nodes, and lymph node involvement is often present even in early disease. In fact, enlarged cervical lymph nodes may be the presenting feature of papillary carcinoma in some cases.

 

Option B. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because medullary carcinoma frequently metastasizes to lymph nodes. Involvement of lymph nodes occurs in 50-60% of cases of medullary carcinoma. This tumor, which arises from parafollicular C cells, also commonly spreads hematogenously, with the liver being the most common site of distant metastasis.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because anaplastic carcinoma is characterized by rapid growth, extensive local invasion, and early lymph node metastasis. Being the most aggressive thyroid malignancy, it shows infiltration of surrounding structures including lymph nodes early in its course, along with distant metastases typically to the lungs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid primarily spreads hematogenously to bones rather than via lymphatics, making it unique among thyroid carcinomas in having a relatively low rate of lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gibson 

 

  • The Gibson incision is correct in this scenario, assuming the surgical mark and procedure are aimed at accessing structures in the lower quadrant of the abdomen or the pelvis. This incision provides the necessary exposure while minimizing damage to the muscular and nerve structures

 

This is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery. It provides excellent exposure to the lower abdomen and pelvic areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robson Incision: This is also known as the "classic gridiron" incision. It's a muscle-splitting incision used primarily for accessing the appendix during an appendectomy. It runs obliquely in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

 

Option B. Battle Incision: Less commonly referenced, this incision isn't widely recognized in standard surgical texts under this name. It may refer to a specialized or less commonly used approach.

 

Option D. Kocher Incision: This incision is typically used for biliary surgery. It is a subcostal incision made parallel to the costal margin, usually on the right side, to provide access to the gallbladder and biliary tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gibson Incision is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a Veress needle which has distinctive features:

 

  • Used for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery using closed technique
  • Has a blunt tip that advances and spring-loaded sharp outer cannula
  • When resistance is overcome, blunt tip springs forward preventing injury to intraabdominal organs
  • Usually inserted in left hypochondrium (Palmer's point) or periumbilical
  • Characteristic "pop" sound heard when it enters peritoneal cavity
  • Can be confirmed by saline drop test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Quincke needle: Incorrect as this is a spinal needle with sharp bevel used for diagnostic/therapeutic lumbar puncture

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle: Incorrect as this is a bone marrow biopsy needle

 

Option D. Aspiration needle: Incorrect as this is for aspiration of fluid collections

 

Educational Objective:

 

Veress needle is used for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery using closed technique and has a characteristic spring-loaded mechanism.

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

questions.text: Which artery is the most common source of Cirsoid Aneurysms of the scalp? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Superficial temporal artery

 

Explanation:

 

Cirsoid aneurysm is an arteriovenous malformation that most commonly affects the superficial temporal vessels on the forehead and scalp. These lesions present as pulsatile masses and represent abnormal communications between arteries and veins without an intervening capillary network. The superficial temporal artery is the primary arterial feeder in these malformations, making it the most common source of cirsoid aneurysms of the scalp.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. External carotid artery: While the external carotid artery is the parent vessel of the superficial temporal artery, it's not directly involved as the primary source of cirsoid aneurysms.
  • Option C. Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid artery supplies intracranial structures and is not directly involved in scalp vascular malformations.
  • Option D. Occipital artery: Although the occipital artery can occasionally contribute to scalp vascular malformations, it is not the most common source of cirsoid aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations predominantly affecting the superficial temporal vessels, presenting as pulsatile masses on the scalp or forehead that require appropriate vascular imaging for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with fever, nausea, rebound tenderness with migration of pain to the right iliac fossa (RIF), raised TLC of 15,000. What is the Alvarado score? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Alvarado score (MANTRELS) is calculated based on specific clinical findings. 

 

 

In this patient:

 

  • Fever scores 1 point, 
  • Nausea scores 1 point, 
  • Rebound tenderness scores 1 point, 
  • Migration of pain to RIF scores 1 point, and 
  • Leukocytosis (TLC 15,000) scores 2 points. 

 

Total score: 1+1+1+1+2 = 6 points.

 

The mnemonic MANTRELS represents: M-Migration (1), A-Anorexia (1), N-Nausea/vomiting (1), T-Tenderness in RIF (1), R-Rebound tenderness (1), E-Elevated temperature/fever (1), L-Leukocytosis (2), S-Shift to left (1). 

 

Remember that Leukocytosis and Tenderness in RIF each score 2 points, while all others score 1 point. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Alvarado scoring for appendicitis, Leukocytosis (L) and Tenderness in RIF (T) each score 2 points, while Migration, Anorexia, Nausea/vomiting, Rebound tenderness, Elevated temperature, and Shift to left each score 1 point.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed

 

The image displays a Romovac drain placed after mastectomy, which is a closed-type drain. Drains are utilized at surgical sites to collect air or fluid buildup, promoting wound healing by preventing cavity formation. Drains can be prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries, with open, semi-open, and closed types.

 

They carry out their actions through suction

 

  • Eg. Romovac drain, Jackson Pratt drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open: They are based on the principle of gravity or capillary effect

 

  • Eg. Corrugated drain, Foleys catheter etc.\

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Romovac drain is a closed negative suction drain placed in subcutaneous tissue and indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. Other specialized drains include chest drains for air removal from the pleural cavity and T-tubes for bile drainage after surgical exploration of the bile duct.

questions.text: Which of the following pathology is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The image provided shows a typical sign of free air under the right dome of the diaphragm. This finding is highly indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. When there is a perforation in any part of the gastrointestinal tract, air can escape into the peritoneal cavity. This air then rises to the highest point in the abdomen when the patient is in an upright position, which is under the diaphragm, and is visible on an upright chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subacute intestinal obstruction: This condition would not present with free air under the diaphragm. Instead, it would typically show dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus would also not present with free air under the diaphragm. It usually shows diffusely dilated bowel loops without a transition point on imaging studies.

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: A pleural effusion involves fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity and would not present with air under the diaphragm. It typically shows fluid in the pleural space on a chest X-ray, often blurring the costophrenic angle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. This is a critical sign that should prompt immediate medical evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

 

Cholangiocarcinoma, a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts, has several well-established risk factors. These include chronic inflammatory conditions like primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), parasitic infections such as Opisthorchis viverrini, and congenital conditions like Caroli's disease. However, while Hepatitis C is recognized as a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma, Hepatitis B is not commonly associated with this type of cancer. The confusion often arises because Hepatitis B is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, another type of liver cancer, but not specifically for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caroli's disease: Caroli's disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the dilation of the bile ducts and is associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): PSC is a chronic liver disease that causes inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts. It is a well-known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Opisthorchis V. (Opisthorchis viverrini): Opisthorchis viverrini, a liver fluke, is a parasitic infection known to increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, especially in endemic regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B infection is not a recognized risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Instead, focus on chronic inflammatory conditions, parasitic infections, and certain congenital disorders as key risk factors for this type of cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy 

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive dysphagia first to solids and then to liquids, along with significant weight loss, are concerning for an esophageal pathology, possibly a malignancy. 

 

This is the investigation of choice for evaluating dysphagia. It allows direct visualization of the esophageal lumen, can detect strictures, masses, or other abnormalities, and offers the possibility of biopsy, which is essential for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This can provide detailed images of the esophageal wall and adjacent structures and is useful for staging esophageal cancer. It is generally not the first test ordered when investigating dysphagia.

 

Option C. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT): While CECT can provide information about the extent of a disease and help in staging cancer, it is not the first-line investigation for dysphagia and cannot provide a definitive diagnosis without endoscopic visualization and biopsy.

 

Option D. Barium swallow: A barium swallow X-ray study can show structural changes in the esophagus, such as narrowing or obstruction, and is useful in diagnosing conditions like achalasia or strictures. However, it is less definitive than endoscopy for tissue diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Upper GI endoscopy is the first-line diagnostic tool for evaluating a patient with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss, as it allows for direct visualization and biopsy to establish a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Mr. Thompson, a 58-year-old male, underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the treatment of gallstones. Following the procedure, he complained of abdominal pain and fever. Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C

 

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg's type C injury.

 

Correct. Strasberg Type C injuries are defined by bile leaks from the major ductal systems, such as the right posterior sectoral duct in this case. The leak can be caused by a missed stone, an unrecognized transection, or an avulsion due to excessive traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Strasberg Type A injuries are characterized by bile leaks from minor ducts or cystic duct that are present either at or near the gallbladder bed. They often present as bile collections in the gallbladder fossa.

 

Option B. Type B: Type B injuries involve an occlusion of the right posterior bile duct. This occlusion might be due to a clip placement or ligature, typically at the time of surgery. It does not involve a bile leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct.

 

Option D. Type D: Type D injuries are characterized by lateral injury or partial transection of extrahepatic bile ducts/Common hepatic hepatic. This would be more extensive than just a leak from an aberrant duct.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Shaving with razor night before operation

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method for hair removal to avoid surgical site infection? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hair clippers on table

 

The sequence of hair removal methods in terms of the least risk of infection is:

 

  • On-table clipping of hair > on-table use of depilatory creams > razor

 

Hair clippers on table:

 

  • Mechanism: Hair clippers trim hair close to the skin without causing micro-abrasions associated with shaving or chemical irritation from depilatory creams. The action is mechanical rather than chemical, minimizing skin irritation.
  • Timing: "On table" means that the hair removal is done immediately before the surgical procedure, leaving minimal time for any bacterial colonization, thus reducing the chances of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shaving with a razor night before operation:

 

  • Risk: Shaving can create micro-abrasions (tiny cuts) in the skin, serving as potential entry points for bacteria. These small wounds might get infected, leading to surgical site infections.
  • Timing: Shaving the night before also provides time for bacteria to colonize these micro-abrasions, increasing the risk of infection.

 

Option B. Depilatory cream before operation:

 

  • Mechanism: Depilatory creams break down hair and do not create the same abrasions as razors.
  • Risk: They can cause skin irritation, potentially leading to a weakened skin barrier. A compromised skin barrier can increase the risk of bacterial invasion and infection.
  • Timing: Using it immediately before the surgery reduces the colonization time for bacteria, but there is still some risk due to potential skin irritation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for hair removal to avoid surgical site infection is using hair clippers immediately before the surgical procedure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

  • The pathological report reveals basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that is commonly found on sun-exposed areas of the body.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • It arises from the basal cells, which are found at the bottom of the epidermis. BCCs are typically slow-growing tumors that rarely metastasize but can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • They commonly appear as pearly nodules with visible blood vessels (telangiectasia), often with a central depression or ulceration.
  • They are commonly found in sun-exposed areas, which makes their presence on the face, especially the nasolabial fold, quite typical.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is one of the most effective treatments for BCC, especially for tumors located in cosmetically sensitive areas, as it ensures complete removal while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is a more aggressive form of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing skin pigment. Melanomas are characterized by their asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, diameter greater than 6mm, and evolving size, shape, or color. They can develop from pre-existing moles or appear de novo. Early detection and treatment are crucial as melanoma has a higher potential for metastasis compared to other skin cancers.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is also commonly found in sun-exposed areas and is associated with chronic sun damage. While it is less aggressive than melanoma, if left untreated, it can grow deeply and cause significant damage. In rare cases, it can also spread to other parts of the body. It shows keratin pearls on histopathology.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign growth on the skin that arises from melanocytes. Moles are usually brown or black and can be located anywhere on the body. They can be present at birth or appear during childhood and adolescence. While most moles are harmless, it is essential to monitor them for changes that might suggest a transformation into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

choices.text: Encephalopathy, AST, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time
Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time

questions.text: Which of these are the components of Child Pugh score? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time.

 

Encephalitis, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time are the components of Child Pugh score

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The components of the Child-Pugh score include encephalopathy, ascites, bilirubin, albumin, and prothrombin time (INR). This scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

questions.text: Earliest/most common symptom of CA esophagus? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysphagia more to solids

 

In carcinoma esophagus:

 

  • Progressive dysphagia first to solids, then to liquids is the earliest and most common symptom
  • Occurs due to mechanical obstruction from tumor growth
  • Liquids can initially pass through a narrowed lumen
  • Typically presents in elderly smoker males
  • By the time symptoms appear, the disease is usually advanced

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia more to liquids:

 

  • Characteristic of motility disorders like achalasia
  • In mechanical obstruction, liquids can initially pass-through

 

Option C. Regurgitation:

 

  • Secondary symptom occurring after dysphagia
  • Not the earliest manifestation
  • Occurs when obstruction becomes significant

 

Option D. Lump:

 

  • Rare presentation in esophageal cancer
  • May occur in cervical esophageal tumors
  • Not an early symptom

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Progressive dysphagia, initially more to solids than liquids, is the earliest and most common symptom of carcinoma esophagus.

choices.text: Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli

questions.text: Where is the most common site for a venous ulcer to develop? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli 

 

Explanation:

 

Venous ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle. The majority of ulcers develop on the medial side of the calf below the malleoli. This is the region where many of the Cockett perforators join the posterior tibial vein to the posterior arch vein (superficial vein). The chronic venous hypertension in this area leads to tissue damage and eventually ulceration when exposed to high venous and capillary pressures chronically.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli: While ulcers associated with short saphenous vein incompetence may develop on the lateral side of the leg, they are less common than medial ulcers.
  • Option C. Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli: Venous ulcers rarely extend into the upper calf, and this location would be uncommon.
  • Option D. Medial aspect of the thigh: Venous ulcers typically occur below the malleoli in the gaiter area rather than thigh.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Venous ulcers most commonly occur on the medial aspect of the ankle below the malleoli (gaiter area) due to the presence of perforating veins and high venous pressure in this region, especially in patients with chronic venous insufficiency.

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a noticeable swelling in his scrotum. After careful evaluation, a decision was made to perform an orchidectomy. The histopathological examination of the tissue reveals the following findings. Based on these findings which of the following diagnoses best describes the patient's condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seminoma

 

  • Morphological - well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Sheets of large, uniform, round or polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.
  • Large central nuclei with prominent nucleoli.
  • Minimal mitotic activity and no or few infiltrating lymphocytes or Syncytiotrophoblast.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yolk-sac tumor:

  • Morphological - Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance.
  • Microscopic features include Schiller-Duval bodies (central vessel surrounded by tumor cells), which resemble a yolk sac.
  • Tumor cells have clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm with small round nuclei and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option C. Embryonal cell carcinoma:

  • Morphological - Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Composed of solid sheets or nests of primitive, undifferentiated cells.
  • Cells are variable in size and shape, with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option D. Teratoma:

  • Morphological - Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types.
  • Composed of multiple germ layers, including ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • May contain a variety of tissues, including skin, hair, bone, cartilage, and neural tissue.
  • Immature teratomas may have undifferentiated, primitive neural or mesenchymal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminoma is a type of germ cell tumor characterized by large, uniform, polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and prominent central nucleoli, often presenting as a well-circumscribed, gray-white, fleshy mass without hemorrhage or necrosis.
